Description:
The American Soup Kitchen (SK) on Tottenham Court Road has been providing food to the homeless, vulnerable, elderly and less fortunate everyday for over 30 years. With the recent COVID-19 related lockdown it witnessed a collapse in its corporate funding. We would like to assist them in raising some money as a result. 

At a time when most other soup kitchens have had to close, the SK has been serving approximately 150 meals per day. They have implemented social distancing measures such as take away meals and ensuring 2 metre distancing between Guests. 

The SK has adopted the government’s guidelines for charities in the work that it does to protect its staff, volunteers and beneficiaries.

For instance the SK has taken steps to protect its staff, volunteers and guests by enforcing social distancing using ground markers and security personnel and by insisting upon the use of sanitizers provided and by asking guests to move on once they’ve collected their hot and cold food parcels.  

We are writing to ask for your help by way of £15 per month for the next three months - so £45 to help see the SK through the worst of this global crisis. Our aim is to get 100 funders on board in this way which will help cover monthly running costs for about 50 Guests until corporate funders return post the lockdown. Over the last ten years we know many of you have supported the fantastic work of the SK, sometimes as volunteers and at other times through donations of food and clothing.  

A massive THANK YOU from us and from the SK ! 

 Paliwal  & Maru Families

﻿This summer we are going to a shanty-town called Las Laderas in Peru with our parents where we will stay in a children's refuge and help to build a new soup kitchen.

Our Dad is a Founding Trustee of the Amoria Bond Charitable Trust which has developed a long-term partnership over the last 10 years with Project Peru and the community of Las Laderas, and has funded and assisted with numerous initiatives including building houses, providing much needed donations of food, IT and sports equipment, and funding the utilities for a local soup kitchen.

Sadly, Las Laderas remains in deep poverty and is growing into increasingly tough and inhospitable terrain up the barren mountain-side. The community's existing single soup-kitchen can not cope with the growing levels of hunger and demand. So the Amoria Bond Charitable Trust has committed to funding the building of an additional new soup-kitchen in 2019 which will provide 100s of meals a week, bring local employment for builders and community workers, and ensure food-security for children and other vulnerable members of the community.

We hope you will donate to help raise the £10,000 it will cost to build the soup kitchen.

THANK YOU!!!

Dylan and Ollie Daw

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Families, like ourselves, who are living with cancer face huge challenges.  The emotional rollercoaster is exhausting and the journey demands energy and resilience that we sometimes lack.  It is, therefore, a huge blessing to receive support from the professional and volunteer staff at the Maggie's Centre in Leeds.

Maggie's is new to Yorkshire.  Their beautiful newly-built Centre is located in the grounds of St James' Hospital in Leeds and opened only weeks before lockdown began.  Their income stream and profile hadn't  time to get established and yet they have remained open to cancer patients and their families throughout the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic,  offering a wide and evolving range of compassionate support from cancer-specific wellbeing groups to financial advice and even song-writing!  We've benefitted personally from a welcome cup of tea and a cry, financial advice and sessions with their Clinical Psychologist to work through some emotional challenges.  All their services are free of charge to patients and their families.

Like most charities, Maggie's needs funds especially at this current time.  As well as inviting you to donate towards the work they are doing for ourselves, and for many others, I hope this fundraising activity will help to increase their profile.  Whilst we are aware of the amazing work of Maggie's, many folk are not.

I've decided to join in with the Maggie's Kitchen Table Day fundraising activities during the coming week - Monday 9 to Friday 13 November -with the two-fold aim of raising funds and their profile.  This weekend the Park family is busy baking goodies for me to sell to the few colleagues I currently interact with around our Covid-secure staff room table!  I'm also aiming to broadcast a brief "Thought for the Evening" from our own kitchen table at 6pm each day via my Facebook page.  

I love the "Kitchen Table" concept that Maggie's has adopted; their "kitchen table" is the focal point for those who visit - to eat and drink together and to share their stories.  It resonates powerfully with me as I think of our own kitchen table and all the precious people who have sat around it to eat and drink and share their stories; it reminds me too of Jesus' invitation to sit, eat and share our lives with him.  So here's to our kitchen table fundraising efforts!

If you are able and would like to donate to the work of Maggie's in Yorkshire please do so by following the instructions on this JustGiving page or by contacting me directly to agree some other way!  

Thank you.

The team in Gleeds Southampton are going to run/walk/swim/row/SUP/cycle as far as we possibly can during the summer of 2020 to raise money for LifeHouse (http://www.lifehouse.org.uk/). 

The Life House is a not-for-profit charity which is a Soup Kitchen and support centre for the homeless and those in need living in Portsmouth and Southsea.

We provide food, hot meals, clothing, counselling and general advice to vulnerable men and women and target the issues of homelessness and addiction locally.

We aim to create an environment of compassion and care, where people feel they belong, are accepted; and where they can build a sense of self-worth and confidence – a place where we can be generous with our time, energy and practical resources; where we can go the extra mile.

The Life House is a converted building which we have outgrown over the years. This means we are limited to the amount of service users that can be seated at any  one seating for the hot meals we provide. We have to ask out service used to queue up outside in the wind and rain and limit the time they can sit and have a rest bite from the elements.

Our intention is to expand so we can accommodate more service users at any one time. The building works we are raising money for will incorporate expanding in to the neighbouring church so we can sit more service users for hot meals. We plans to increase the capacity of the existing kitchen and make it more operationally efficient to help free up volunteers for they can focus on helping the service users.  

We would also like to expand to offer more services such as online training, expand our counselling service, hair dressing, and other wellbeing services such as, podiatry and medical advice etc.

Description:
We will be able soon, with your generous support, to seat and feed double the number of homeless, underhoused and rehabilitating guests 2-3 times a week in this new, large, comfortable space. For the first time they will all be able to choose where they sit and for how long (especially vital in cold and wet weather when rough sleepers need to take time to “warm-up” and dry out). The newly enlarged LifeHouse will seat 50-55 diners, not the 28 we squeeze in now!

Our guests will not be hurried along to make way for the next person. Sadly queueing outside in all weathers had been a regular feature of the LifeHouse up to now.  On a Thursday evening diners can enjoy some live music from all sorts of local artists free of charge. So this can become an unhurried, dignified and sociable meal out for our guests rather than a short, scrambled meal limited by time and have coffee after in the sofa area.

The major design, surveying, permissions and building work, is being done and very generously paid for by PMC Construction: www.pmcconstruction.co.uk.  Since 1982, PMC Construction has developed housing and commercial schemes that are built to last.

The front of the building seen here will be the new, main dining room and we hope that you might decide to help us refurbish and equip it! The lighting is very outdated and needs replacing. We will need a range of trolleys and serving equipment. The old diner area will be kept to provide a space where people can get support can sit, have coffee, play table football or table-tennis or just chill out and socialise - something they don’t get to do before. 

In this season ahead we need to fund decoration, folding tables,
lighting, heated food trays, trolleys, extra fridge and floor coverings.

Written on 29.01.2020

In April 2020, it will be two years since I started my running journey with a Couch to 5K course.  So what better way to mark that anniversary than with a full marathon in Brighton.  The whole 26.2 miles.  Eeek!

Outdoor running wasn't something that I thought I would enjoy or be any good at...(I really didn't like cross country at school!)...but I soon found a huge passion for it, that I never knew I had.  Especially trail running or road running with great views.  I'm very lucky that I live next to the sea and nearby forests to explore.  The support of a great running club has made a massive difference.  Social running is never dull.

I normally  do races just for fun...but running my first marathon provides the perfect opportunity to help a worth while local cause.  

I first heard about the Lifehouse charity when I took part in the Great South running weekend with colleagues back in October 2018.  We jointly raised funds and I knew it was a charity I would like to support again.  They do a fantastic job supporting the homeless and those with addictions in Southsea.  If you can help at all please, that would be marvellous! 

11-09-20 UPDATE

We all know Covid-19 tried to get in the way of us having fun. The Brighton marathon was of course cancelled.   I was gutted.  I am still determined to run a marathon though, as soon as I can!

The plan is to run the Portsmouth Coastal Marathon on 20th December.  I'm about to properly restart my long distance training.  I haven't let my fitness slip at all during lockdown ...so feeling ready to do this.

06-11-20 UPDATE

The Portsmouth Coastal marathon was cancelled in October, so a new plan was quickly hatched.  My husband and I signed up to the God of Thunder II race at Denbies wine estates in Dorking.  This was a 5K lapped event that took place on 1st November.  We managed 8 laps for the full marathon distance!  This wasn't a flat marathon.  There was 2,600 feet of elevation thrown in for fun!

The medal was rather epic.  See photo above.

I am so pleased we both managed to run our first marathons in 2020 after all!

Thank you for reading

Description:
This year the Body Shop have partnered up with the End Youth Homelessness movement - a coalition of charities who have joined forces to solve the youth homelessness crisis in the United Kingdom and Ireland. Violence, abuse, neglect and problems with mental health - young people often become homeless because it's safer to leave home than to stay, a devastating reality which shouldn’t be endured by anyone, but sadly is the case for over 110,000 young people* right now.

That’s why my team, The Dream Catchers, and I as independent consultants with The Body Shop at Home have decided to sign up and take part in this year’s Virtual Sleep Out (or In) on the 20th November 2020. As some of us have young children we’ve decided to sleep for the night on our kitchen floors with just a sleeping bag, to experience what it’s like for young people who find themselves sleeping on the cold, hard, unforgiving streets. As a team of young people and mothers this reality for so many young people finding themselves without a safe home environment, no roof over their heads and an uncertain future is absolutely heartbreaking which is why we want to help raise crucial funds for the End Youth Homelessness movement and help bring an end to this sooner rather than later. 

Every £100 raised from your donations for our Virtual Sleep Out could provide four night’s accommodation for a young person with no where else to go. That’s four nights sleeping safely with a roof over their head, in a dry, warm bed.

As a thank you for your support, every person that donates will be added to a free prize draw to win a free Body Shop product bundle worth at least £50 and the winner will be announced using a random number generator LIVE on Facebook on the 21st November (the link for this will be posted in here prior to the LIVE prize draw). Let’s work together to get homeless youths of the street this winter and hope for a better future.

#ComeTogetherActTogether 

*Source: Centrepoint’s Youth Homelessness Databank

Description:
Maggie's is charity offering the best possible support to anyone with cancer - and their families - from centres alongside NHS hospitals and also online.

They have Support Specialists, Psychologists, Benefits Advisors and a strong online community.

All support is free and no appointment or referral is necessary.

Maggie's help people take back control when cancer turns life upside down, with professional support for anything from treatment side effects to money worries.

Together with the University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust Maggie's are working to bring cancer support of the highest quality to the South of England and are currently in the process of building a centre in the grounds of Southampton General Hospital. 

Maggie’s still have £1 million to raise and have done a fundraising “shout out” to help raise funds to finish building the centre and cover the running costs of the 1st year of being open.

COVID-19 has, of course, affected cancer care and Maggie's are working alongside the NHS to help people cope with the uncertainty and stress at this time by offering them the best psychological support.

They also are working hard to ensure that people with cancer do not become the collateral of this pandemic.  

Many essential medical treatments for non-COVID-19 patients stopped, elective surgical procedures were put on hold, screening for serious illnesses such as cancer were suspended, diagnostic tests cancelled, and important clinical trials were suspended.

While the NHS response to the pandemic has been incredible, many patients with cancer have been left unable to access urgent diagnostics and treatment.

As a law firm specialising in serious personal injury and medical negligence with many years’ experience helping people who have suffered avoidable harmed due to misdiagnosis and delays in
diagnosis and treatment, we are deeply concerned about the safety of patients with medical conditions unrelated to COVID-19.

Therefore, we recognise the importance of supporting services such as Maggie’s and taking part in their fundraising activities, including their #KitchenTableDay to raise essential funds.
